ground_truth.context: A 7‑year‑old male presented with a 3‑month history of progressive gait instability, diplopia, and morning headaches. MRI of the brain revealed a diffuse intrinsic pontine mass measuring 3.2 cm in the anteroposterior dimension, hyperintense on T2, with minimal contrast enhancement. Stereotactic biopsy confirmed a diffuse midline glioma, WHO grade IV, harboring the H3K27M mutation (K27M substitution in HIST1H3B) and a co‑occurring ACVR1 G328V activating mutation. The patient also has a known diagnosis of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) but no other germline alterations. He underwent focal conformal radiation therapy to a total dose of 54 Gy delivered in 30 fractions over 6 weeks. Concurrently, he was enrolled in a Phase I/II clinical trial (NCT04222972) evaluating the combination of ONC201 (a dopamine receptor D2 antagonist) at 625 mg/m² administered intravenously once weekly and panobinostat (a pan‑HDAC inhibitor) at 20 mg/m² given orally three times weekly. At the 8‑week post‑radiation assessment, repeat MRI demonstrated a 30 % reduction in the tumor’s T2 hyperintense volume, meeting criteria for a partial radiographic response. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) analysis showed a decline in the H3K27M allele frequency from 12 % at baseline to 4 % after treatment. The trial’s interim analysis reported a median overall survival of 14 months for patients with H3K27M‑mutant DIPG receiving the ONC201 + panobinostat regimen, compared with a historical control median OS of 11 months (hazard ratio 0.78, p = 0.04). No Grade ≥ 3 toxicities have been observed in this patient to date; laboratory monitoring shows stable liver function tests and no cytopenias.

ground_truth.context:
A 7‑year‑old male presented with progressive ataxia and cranial nerve palsies. MRI revealed a classic diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) spanning the pons. Molecular profiling of the biopsy specimen demonstrated a heterozygous H3F3A‑K27M mutation and a concurrent ACVR1‑R206H activating mutation. Baseline hepatic panel was normal. The patient completed standard focal radiation therapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions) three weeks ago.

Because of the dual H3‑K27M/ACVR1 genotype, the oncology team enrolled him in the multi‑center Phase I/II trial NCT04567890, which evaluates the oral DRD2 antagonist ONC201 combined with the histone deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat. The protocol specifies ONC201 at 625 mg/m² administered orally once weekly and panobinostat at 20 mg/m² given orally three times per week (Monday, Wednesday, Friday) for a 28‑day cycle.

Interim analysis of the trial reported that patients with both H3‑K27M and ACVR1 mutations who received the combination therapy had a median overall survival (OS) of 13 months, compared with 9 months for those receiving ONC201 monotherapy (p = 0.04).

Pharmacogenomic testing revealed that the patient carries a CYP3A4*22 loss‑of‑function allele, which is known to reduce panobinostat clearance by approximately 30 %. The trial protocol includes a dose‑modification guideline: for patients with a confirmed CYP3A4 loss‑of‑function variant, reduce the panobinostat dose by 25 % from the standard 20 mg/m² regimen.

The patient’s body surface area (BSA) is calculated at 1.0 m². No other contraindications are present.

ground_truth.context: A 7‑year‑old male presented with a 3‑month history of progressive gait instability, diplopia, and morning headaches. MRI of the brain revealed a diffuse intrinsic pontine mass measuring 3.2 cm in the anteroposterior dimension, hyperintense on T2, with minimal contrast enhancement. Stereotactic biopsy confirmed a diffuse midline glioma, WHO grade IV, harboring the H3K27M mutation (K27M substitution in HIST1H3B) and a co‑occurring ACVR1 G328V activating mutation. The patient also has a known diagnosis of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) but no other germline alterations. He underwent focal conformal radiation therapy to a total dose of 54 Gy delivered in 30 fractions over 6 weeks. Concurrently, he was enrolled in a Phase I/II clinical trial (NCT04222972) evaluating the combination of ONC201 (a dopamine receptor D2 antagonist) at 625 mg/m² administered intravenously once weekly and panobinostat (a pan‑HDAC inhibitor) at 20 mg/m² given orally three times weekly. At the 8‑week post‑radiation assessment, repeat MRI demonstrated a 30 % reduction in the tumor’s T2 hyperintense volume, meeting criteria for a partial radiographic response. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) analysis showed a decline in the H3K27M allele frequency from 12 % at baseline to 4 % after treatment. The trial’s interim analysis reported a median overall survival of 14 months for patients with H3K27M‑mutant DIPG receiving the ONC201 + panobinostat regimen, compared with a historical control median OS of 11 months (hazard ratio 0.78, p = 0.04). No Grade ≥ 3 toxicities have been observed in this patient to date; laboratory monitoring shows stable liver function tests and no cytopenias.

ground_truth.context:
A 7‑year‑old male presented with progressive ataxia and cranial nerve palsies. MRI revealed a classic diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) spanning the pons. Molecular profiling of the biopsy specimen demonstrated a heterozygous H3F3A‑K27M mutation and a concurrent ACVR1‑R206H activating mutation. Baseline hepatic panel was normal. The patient completed standard focal radiation therapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions) three weeks ago.

Because of the dual H3‑K27M/ACVR1 genotype, the oncology team enrolled him in the multi‑center Phase I/II trial NCT04567890, which evaluates the oral DRD2 antagonist ONC201 combined with the histone deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat. The protocol specifies ONC201 at 625 mg/m² administered orally once weekly and panobinostat at 20 mg/m² given orally three times per week (Monday, Wednesday, Friday) for a 28‑day cycle.

Interim analysis of the trial reported that patients with both H3‑K27M and ACVR1 mutations who received the combination therapy had a median overall survival (OS) of 13 months, compared with 9 months for those receiving ONC201 monotherapy (p = 0.04).

Pharmacogenomic testing revealed that the patient carries a CYP3A4*22 loss‑of‑function allele, which is known to reduce panobinostat clearance by approximately 30 %. The trial protocol includes a dose‑modification guideline: for patients with a confirmed CYP3A4 loss‑of‑function variant, reduce the panobinostat dose by 25 % from the standard 20 mg/m² regimen.

The patient’s body surface area (BSA) is calculated at 1.0 m². No other contraindications are present.
